Package io.github.hexagonnico.vecmat.vector

Record Class Double3

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Record
io.github.hexagonnico.vecmat.vector.Double3
Record Components:
x - First coordinate of the vector
y - Second coordinate of the vector
z - Third coordinate of the vector
All Implemented Interfaces:
VectorDoubleOperations<Double3>, VectorOperations<Double3>
public record Double3(double x, double y, double z) extends Record implements VectorDoubleOperations<Double3>
Record that represents a 3D double vector.
Author:
Nico

  • Method Details

    • plus

      public Double3 plus(double x, double y, double z)
      Computes the sum of this vector with the given one.

      The sum of two vectors v1 and v2 of the same size is a vector v3 such that every i-th element of v3 is the sum of the i-th element of v1 and the i-th element of v2.

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Parameters:
      x - First coordinate of the given vector.
      y - Second coordinate of the given vector.
      z - Third coordinate of the given vector.
      Returns:
      The sum of this vector and the given one.

    • plus

      public Double3 plus(Double3 vector)
      Description copied from interface: VectorOperations
      Computes the sum of this vector with the given one.

      The sum of two vectors v1 and v2 of the same size is a vector v3 such that every i-th element of v3 is the sum of the i-th element of v1 and the i-th element of v2.

      Two vectors can only be summed if their size is the same.

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Specified by:
      plus in interface VectorOperations<Double3>
      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the sum, a vector of the same type and same size as this one.
      Returns:
      The sum of this vector and the given one.

    • negated

      public Double3 negated()
      Description copied from interface: VectorOperations
      Computes the additive inverse of this vector.

      The additive inverse of a vector v is a vector -v such that v + (-v) is a vector where every element i is 0.

      Specified by:
      negated in interface VectorOperations<Double3>
      Returns:
      The additive inverse of this vector.

    • minus

      public Double3 minus(double x, double y, double z)
      Computes the subtraction of the given vector from this one.

      The subtraction of a vector v2 from a vector v1 is defined as the sum of v1 with the additive inverse of v2. That is v1 - v2 = v1 + (-v2)

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Parameters:
      x - First coordinate of the given vector.
      y - Second coordinate of the given vector.
      z - Third coordinate of the given vector.
      Returns:
      The sum of this vector and the additive inverse of the given one.

    • multipliedBy

      public Double3 multipliedBy(double k)
      Description copied from interface: VectorDoubleOperations
      Computes the multiplication between this vector and a scalar.

      The product between a vector v and a scalar k is a vector where every element i is the i-th element of v multiplied by k.

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Specified by:
      multipliedBy in interface VectorDoubleOperations<Double3>
      Parameters:
      k - The scalar to which this vector is multiplied.
      Returns:
      The product between this vector and the given scalar.

    • dividedBy

      public Double3 dividedBy(double k)
      Description copied from interface: VectorDoubleOperations
      Computes the division between this vector and a scalar.

      The division of a vector v by a scalar k is defined as the multiplication between v and the multiplicative inverse 1/k. See VectorDoubleOperations.multipliedBy(double).

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Specified by:
      dividedBy in interface VectorDoubleOperations<Double3>
      Parameters:
      k - The scalar by which this vector is divided.
      Returns:
      The product between this vector and the multiplicative inverse of the given scalar.

    • dotProduct

      public double dotProduct(double x, double y, double z)
      Computes the dot product (or scalar product) between this vector and the given one.

      The dot product between two vectors v and w of the same size is a scalar defined as the summation of the products of every element vi and wi of the two vectors.

      Parameters:
      x - First coordinate of the given vector.
      y - Second coordinate of the given vector.
      z - Third coordinate of the given vector.
      Returns:
      The result of the dot product between the two vectors.

    • dotProduct

      public double dotProduct(Double3 vector)
      Description copied from interface: VectorDoubleOperations
      Computes the dot product (or scalar product) between this vector and the given one.

      The dot product between two vectors v and w of the same size is a scalar defined as the summation of the products of every element vi and wi of the two vectors.

      The dot product can only be computed between two vectors of the same size.

      Specified by:
      dotProduct in interface VectorDoubleOperations<Double3>
      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the product, another double vector of the same size as this one.
      Returns:
      The result of the dot product between the two vectors.

    • crossProduct

      public Double3 crossProduct(double x, double y, double z)
      Computes the cross product (or vector product) between this vector and the given one.

      The cross product between two 3D vectors is a vector perpendicular to both of them whose magnitude equals the area of the parallelogram with the two vectors for sides.

      Parameters:
      x - First coordinate of the given vector.
      y - Second coordinate of the given vector.
      z - Third coordinate of the given vector.
      Returns:
      The result of the cross product between the two vectors.

    • crossProduct

      public Double3 crossProduct(Double3 vector)
      Computes the cross product (or vector product) between this vector and the given one.

      The cross product between two 3D vectors is a vector perpendicular to both of them whose magnitude equals the area of the parallelogram with the two vectors for sides.

      If the given vector is null, it will be treated as a vector where every element is 0.

      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the product.
      Returns:
      The result of the cross product between the two vectors.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given vector is null.

    • crossProduct

      public Double3 crossProduct(VectorAsDouble<Double3> vector)
      Computes the cross product (or vector product) between this vector and the given one.

      The cross product between two 3D vectors is a vector perpendicular to both of them whose magnitude equals the area of the parallelogram with the two vectors for sides.

      The cross product between this vector and a vector that can be represented as a double vector without casting will result in a double vector.

      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the product.
      Returns:
      The result of the cross product between the two vectors.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given vector is null.

    • lengthSquared

      public double lengthSquared()
      Description copied from interface: VectorDoubleOperations
      Computes the squared length (or squared magnitude) of this vector.

      When one needs to compare the length of two vectors, it is best to use this method instead of VectorDoubleOperations.length(), since given two numbers a > b, then it also holds that a^2 > b^2, and this method is more efficient since it does not compute a square root.

      Specified by:
      lengthSquared in interface VectorDoubleOperations<Double3>
      Returns:
      The squared length (or squared magnitude) of this vector.

      public final boolean equals(Object o)
      Indicates whether some other object is "equal to" this one. The objects are equal if the other object is of the same class and if all the record components are equal. All components in this record class are compared with '=='.
